author: Special Correspondent
text:
The recent decision of the Kerala State Government to restrict sales of on liquor has not affected the inflow of tourists into the State, said P. Muraleedharan, Tourist Information Officer.

Talking to reporters on the sidelines of a road show to showcase the tourism potential of Kerala, Mr. Muraleedharan said that the state, through its sought after Ayurveda treatments and scenic backwaters, sets a target of 10 per cent growth in tourism and achieved at least 8.5 to 9 per cent every year. While the liquor ban had led to some events being shifted to star hotels, it did not affect then umber of visiting tourists.

In 2014, 9,23,366 foreign tourists and 1,16,95,411 domestic tourists visited the State. As of October 2015, 7,75,390 foreign tourists and 76,71,277 domestic tourists were recorded. Tourist season in Kerala usually peaks in the months from November to February and the footfall is expected to surpass 2014 comfortably, he added.

April 2015 to April 2016 is being promoted by the Kerala Government as "Visit Kerala Year," he said.
title: ‘Restriction on liquor sales has not hit Kerala tourism’
